content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. Unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code, specifically as amounts includible in gross income by reason of the discharge of indebtedness. These payments refer to applicable child support payments required under a support instrument for the taxpayer's child. The Internal Revenue Code treats unpaid child support payments as taxable income, specifically as amounts included in gross income by the discharge of indebtedness. The taxpayer must send a notice to the individual who failed to make payments, including the amount of applicable child support payments for the taxable year and a requirement to include this amount in gross income. The Internal Revenue Code requires unpaid child support payments to be included in gross income for the preceding taxable year. If the taxpayer's address is unknown, the Secretary will send a notice if the address is available. If there is no known address, no income will be included for any taxable year before the year in which notice can be sent. The Internal Revenue Code mandates that unpaid child support payments must be included in gross income for the previous taxable year. Any subsequent payments can be deducted in the year they are made. Definitions for "applicable child support payments" and "eligible taxpayer" are provided in section 166(f). Net revenues from this Act will be used solely to pay off the US public debt, as specified in appropriation Acts, and cannot be used for any other purpose.
